title: The Past Fortnight on TV #46
body:
Latest TV review: the Battle of Winterfell & its aftermath on #GameOfThrones. Also #BBCGhosts, classic #TwilightZone, and more:

I’m throwing off the usual monthly format of these TV reviews to keep up with coverage of Game of Thrones. This time: the Battle of Winterfell and its aftermath. Next time: the series finale!

Also this fortnight: new BBC fantasy sitcom Ghosts, the first (sort of) episode of Columbo, the latest editions of Mark Kermode’s Secrets of Cinema and Thronecast, and more of the best tales from The…

summary: I don't usually post stuff like this on here. But whenever I put this stuff on I feel like an indulgent medieval queen soaking...
body:
I don’t usually post stuff like this on here. But whenever I put this stuff on I feel like an indulgent medieval queen soaking in a bath of rose petals and ordering her servants around.

Okay, so basically I feel like Cersei.

@monikafilefan @momdadimpoppunk @wtfmulder

summary: Out of all the things GoT 8.04 did wrong, the one thing I consistently get angrier about every time I think about it is...
body:
Out of all the things GoT 8.04 did wrong, the one thing I consistently get angrier about every time I think about it is Missandei’s death. Here’s is a beautiful, brilliant, capable woman, one of the oldest and best friends (if not the best friend) Daenarys has left, a former slave girl, who Daenarys was not even really planning on taking with her at first (freeing yes, that’s her thing, but she really only needed the unsullied) but Missandei impressed her so much with her quick translations of super disgusting shit to polite buisness interaction, that Daenarys basically went “this one. i want this one” and then the first thing she did was ask if she had a family to return to and told her “Yes all men must die, but we are not men”.

Missandei was brilliant and Daenarys freed her and they became best friends and out of all of her advisors Missandei is probably the one who understood Dany the best.

Missandei isn’t a fighter, but she showed that you don’t need to be a fighter to be brilliant and important and strong. She was freed and she took that new life with both hands and became Daenarys most trusted advisor, found love, was absolutely brilliant! … and then she dies in chains.

I’ve said I wish she had pushed Cersei off the wall and at least taken her down with her, but I don’t even know if that would have made it better. It’s just… Missandei’s death doesn’t feel right at all. No death ever feels good, but Theon worked I guess, Jorah made sense, they died on their own terms, for the people they loved. Missandei died (just like Rhaegal) simply to be one more loss for Daenarys, to somehow justify Dany becoming the “mad queen” when that is so clearly not who the queen Missandei followed would ever become. (also possibly for Grey Worm’s character developement if they wanna do something with him)

And she died in chains. As a plot device to somehow justify the decent of her best friend into madness. Killed by Cersei, like she did not matter at all. In chains. With Cersei throwing Daenarys’ “Breaker of Chains” title in her face.

She deserved so so so much better.

Dracarys.

summary: What if the last episode includes a shot of Jaime going to Tarth, seeing a small blond baby/child, realizing it’s his, and...
body:
What if the last episode includes a shot of Jaime going to Tarth, seeing a small blond baby/child, realizing it’s his, and finding out Brienne died in childbirth?  

If this happens, I will not be pleased, because I feel like it would reduce Brienne to a female character who exists solely to enhance a male character’s story.  

And I don’t think GRRM would do that to us.  He wouldn’t give us Brienne POV chapters for an entire book if Brienne only served to make Jaime’s narrative “bittersweet”.
